sen.j: 骨傘（ほねからかさ）は、鳥山石燕の『百器徒然袋』に描かれる日本の妖怪。
sen.e: Honekarakasa is a Japanese specter portrayed in "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (One hundred bags in idlenss) by Sekien TORIYAMA.

A Hone-karakasa (literally, an oil-paper umbrella with a bamboo frame, the oil paper of which is gone) is one of Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) that was portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book: "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (The Bag of One Hundred Random Demons; the term 'hyakki' in its title is a pun on the usual hyakki, replacing the character for demon which is written as "鬼" in Japanese with a character for vessel written as "器," and sure enough, most of the yokais shown in this book are tsukumogami [a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive]).
sen.cmt: スペルミス、補足訳

sen.e: It is the specter of a Chinese umbrella and considered as a kind of Tsukumo-gami (gods to a variety of things).

sen.j: 傘布が剥がれて骨ばかりとなった古い唐傘が、鳥のように宙を舞う姿で描かれている。
sen.e: An old Chinese umbrella that has no cloth but only ribs is portrayed in the air flying like a bird.
An old karakasa whose oil paper is gone and only ribs remain is portrayed flying in the air like a bird.
sen.cmt: 補足、用語

sen.j: 妖怪漫画家・水木しげるの説によれば、古びた傘が温度と湿り気によってこの妖怪となり、踊りだすともいう。
sen.e: According to, specter cartoonist Shigeru MIZUKI, moisture and temperature make an old umbrella into this specter and to dance.
According to a yokai cartoonist named Shigeru MIZUKI, temperature and moisture affect an old karakasa by causing it to transmute into this yokai and dance.
sen.cmt: 語順、用語、不要な句読点
sen.e: According to a yokai cartoonist named Shigeru MIZUKI, temperature and moisture affect an old karakasa by causing it to transmute into this yokai and dance.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 鴟吻（鴟尾）は日本における鯱の原型とされ、雨を呼ぶ火災よけの呪物とされている。
sen.e: The shifun (shifun) is thought be a prototypal of shachihoko (often seen atop the tiled ridgepoles of castles, placed as ornamentation and fire prevention) and considered as a magical object, which brings rain to prevent fire.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: The shifun (or shibi are ornamental tiles often seen atop the tiled ridgepoles of castles, placed as ornamentation and fire prevention) is thought to be a prototype of shachihoko (mythical carp with the head of a lion and the body of a fish, which are auspicious protectors of well-being) and regarded as charms to bring the rain for fire prevention.
sen.cmt: 原文の誤読。補足・修正。しゃちほこの定訳はtangorin.comからの引用です。
